message.content: This question requires knowledge about the role of worms in the ecosystem. Option (A) is partially correct, as worms do eat rotting organic material, but it does not fully explain why they are excellent decomposers. Option (B) is incorrect because worms primarily eat dead plant material, not dead bodies. Option (C) is the correct answer because worms consume carcasses and other organic matter, and their waste products contribute to nutrient cycling and soil fertility. Option (D) is incorrect because worms do not primarily eat dirt and decay, but rather organic material.

This question requires knowledge about the role of worms in decomposition. Option (C) is the correct answer because worms are excellent decomposers as they consume carcasses and organic matter and then excrete waste, known as castings, that enrich the soil. Option (A) is incorrect because worms do not specifically eat rot but rather organic matter in general. Option (B) is incorrect because worms typically do not eat dead bodies but rather feed on decaying organic matter. Option (D) is incorrect because worms do not eat dirt, although they do benefit from the nutrients found in soil.

This question requires basic knowledge about the role of worms in decomposition. Option (C) is correct because worms consume carcasses and organic matter, digest it, and expel waste (known as castings) back into the soil, which helps to recycle nutrients and break down dead material. Option (D) is incorrect because worms do not eat dirt, but rather consume organic matter in the soil.
